['Joules (J) - The International System of Units (SI) derived unit for energy, which includes heat as a form of energy transfer.', 'Calorie (cal) - Traditionally used in nutrition and thermodynamics; equal to 4.184 joules.', 'British thermal unit (BTU) - A traditional unit of heat commonly used in the US, equal to approximately 1055 joules.', 'Therm (thm) - An obsolete energy-based unit that was primarily used for heating and cooling purposes; 28.3 BTUs.', 'Kilocalorie (kcal) or food calorie - Used to measure the amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of one kilogram of water by one degree Celsius, equal to 1000 calories.', 'Tesla (T) - A derived unit for magnetic flux density; not directly a measurement of heat but can be involved in heat generation through electromagnetic processes.', 'Erg - An obsolete CGS unit that is equivalent to exactly 8.192 joules, rarely used today.', 'Kilojoule (kJ) - A derived SI unit for energy, equal to one thousand joules; commonly used to express the amount of heat transferred or produced in various processes.', 'Watt-hour (Wh) - A derived unit that represents power consumption over time; 1 watt-hour equals 3600 joules', 'Reaumur degree (°Ra or °Re) - An obsolete temperature scale where the melting point of ice and the boiling point of water were set at 0 and 80 respectively; indirectly related to measuring heat as it involves thermal energy changes.', 'Heat flux - A vector quantity representing the rate of transfer of heat through a given surface area, typically measured in watts per square meter (W/m²).', 'Thermochemistry - The branch of chemistry that deals with the relationship between chemical reactions and energy changes involving heat.', 'Entropy change (ΔS) - In thermodynamics, it represents a measure of disorder or randomness within a system, indirectly related to heat exchange processes in certain contexts.', 'Thermodynamic equilibrium - The state reached by a physical system when competing opposing forces such as temperature gradients (related to heat transfer) are balanced and no further changes occur.', 'Specific heat capacity - A material property that indicates how much heat energy is required to raise the temperature of one gram of a substance by one degree Celsius, indirectly related because it involves heat absorption/release during temperature change.', "Heat transfer coefficient (U) - The measure of a fluid's ability to transport thermal energy from one point to another; used in calculations involving convection processes.", 'Calorimetry - A scientific technique that measures the amount of heat involved in chemical reactions or physical changes, using calorimeters designed for this purpose.', 'Heat engine - A device that converts thermal energy into mechanical work following the principles of thermodynamics and includes units like watts (power) which indirectly relates to heat production/use.', 'Specific latent heat - The amount of heat per unit mass required for a phase change at constant temperature, often discussed in terms of heating or cooling processes involving phase transitions (e.g., melting, freezing).', 'Joule-second (J·s) - A derived SI unit that represents energy multiplied by time; not directly used to measure heat but appears in the study of quantum mechanics and statistical physics where energy exchanges occur over discrete quanta.']
